newsitem.title: TUNISIA: Tunisia opens market to private Internet suppliers.
newsitem.headline: Tunisia opens market to private Internet suppliers.

text.p: Tunisia has issued legislation opening the local market to private Internet and other telecommunications services suppliers.
The legislation was in the last issue of the Official Gazetta received on Tuesday.

It allows private companies to set up Internet servers connected to the state's telecommunications services and to offer Internet services to local subscribers provided they vet the network's content.
"The director (of the server's company) must keep outwatching constantly the servers' content...in order to not let in informations against the public order and moral values," the legislation says.
The state-controlled Tunisian Internet Agency said it has launched a tender to select two companies which will be allowed licence to manage such servers.
Since last year, access to Internet was allowed only through the state's agency.

Individual Internet subscribers currently pay 500 dinars to be connected and a 150 dinars fee per month. Telecommunciations sources said the opening up of the service to private suppliers could substantially cut the fees.
The new legislation also opens videotex, audiotex, databases, E-Mail, TelNet, File Transfer Protocol (FTP) and Newsgroups services to private suppliers.
Fernando de Sousa, Microsoft's China marketing manager for business systems, said the emphasis was on closed intranet networks rather than on expanding local access to the global Internet.
"China is not so much interested in people surfing the Web," he said. "Most of the projects in China are intranets."

After a high-profile confrontation with China in the early 1990s over control and development of the Chinese version of the Windows operating system, Microsoft has in the past year signed a series of agreements cementing its position here.
Last month, it signed an agreement with China's top personal computer maker, the Legend Group, under which it will be allowed to pre-install Chinese-language Windows 95 in its PCs.

Microsoft's general manager for China, Jia-Bin Duh, said revenues in China were "more than doubling" every year, adding that sales of server operating systems accounted for more than 50 percent of the company's China business.
He said that in the past year Microsoft had sold more than 10,000 copies of its Windows NT server software package, which commands a street price of around 10,000 yuan ($1,200).
The company is currently investing in its future in China, particularly in terms of people and staff, Duh said, but declined to predict when Microsoft China might move into profit.
"There is no specific target. But we're confident about this market. We'll get there, but there's no exact target," he said.
Chase said piracy of Microsoft products remained a major problem in China, but he added that significant progress was apparent in cracking down on the pirates.
"It's hard to tell, but I understand the price of pirate CD-ROMs is getting higher," de Sousa said. "I was told they have increased by 30 percent recently."
